text: [Music]
hi everyone
here the internet's busiest music nerd
and it's time for a review of this new
black dresses album forget your own face
this is a brand new project from the
music duo black dresses debbie mccallion
and aydah rook are back it's awesome to
see them keeping the momentum up after
releasing forever in your heart just a
year ago a project that essentially
brought the duo back from a short-lived
breakup and now with this new sudden
release it's pretty clear they're here
to stay forget your own face is far from
black dresses biggest project yet it's
uh just 20 minutes eight tracks long but
it's still a very unique project for
them packed with these explosive
feelings of loathing self-loathing anger
focused into an almost industrial noise
wrap rage in a way i can understand why
this project is so short and so separate
because maybe devi and aydah didn't want
the feelings and messaging on this
specific record to bleed over into
everything else they've been doing
creatively this project does feel like a
dark dark continuation of the emotional
evolution that black dresses have been
undergoing over the course of their
major projects look at peaceful as hell
or forever in your heart where there are
tons of tracks on these records that
reflect on
the ugliness of the world how horrid it
is full of hate but typically with black
dresses there is a fighting spirit
behind that acknowledgement about not
giving up on love and hope and faith in
humanity not giving up on yourself as
well and by comparison on forget your
face a lot of tracks are sounding
harsher and as if they are losing that
internal struggle these lyrics are fired
off in the midst of the chaotic dance
beats of earthworm which is a track that
very much stresses about the dichotomy
of having to be a good person or wanting
to be a good person while also i guess
there being bad elements of you as well
and really uh having to reconcile the
two or you know trend more toward the
good because that is a in the past for
black dresses it's been a personal
preference but there's still a lot of
negative self-perception on these tracks
that is pushing things emotionally down
a darker path though it seems like what
also may be fueling it is this desire to
be more understandable either to others
or yourself uh be more consistent not
have to worry about being one thing or
the other or both there's a similar
struggle to be something people can
understand or define on the song no
normal which is an explosive noise pop
anthem all about just not fitting in
with devi lyrically engaging in some
very sharp self mockery about the duo of
success so far in the underground but
even in the midst of all of this
negativity and again a very chaotic
instrumental devi and aydah just have
such incredible vocal and artistic
chemistry they're just so on the same
page because they really do pack
a full
gratifying multi-sectioned and visceral
song into a two-minute run time so there
is most definitely a method to their
madness the song doom spiral uh
certainly sounds like one it is a gentle
lo-fi but distorted ballad with all of
these bass tones that are blasted out to
the point where they're clipping into
oblivion but despite sounding so rough
around the edges the chord progressions
the melody lines that debbie and ada
come up with here are beautiful but on
the lyrical end we are diving into a lot
of themes of feeling worthless and also
self-sabotage another wasted chance
another falling star lands in my hands
and i snuff it out another lifeless day
another ray of light bathes me in hope
and i step aside which is an interesting
angle to take as the narrator of this
song because in one breath
you are acknowledging that there is like
a light there that there's a positive
path that there is a good option to take
but simultaneously you're in a mindset
where you don't see it you don't accept
it and in a way you're just rejecting it
there are a couple of moments in the
track list here where the duo goes
completely berserk money makes you
stupid this track this beat these vocals
i think are some of the most unhinged
black dresses have ever done on
record the sensation of this track i
imagine is what it's like to be struck
by lightning or thrown into a pool of
molten lava the zany twisted layers of
carnival synths the really aggressive
pounding industrial beats and bass that
sound like something from a hard ass
fear factory record plus the rap
breakdowns and heavy chugging guitars in
the second half like i'm just
continually blown away by how hard black
dresses can go on a track and how
boundaryless their creativity and
genre lines are on cuts like this
there's also the opener which i think
sets the tone of this lp in a lot of
ways in terms of the negativity and the
self-loathing but uh it almost runs like
a diss track lyrically and reading into
debbie's bars maybe even a self-diss
track because a lot of what she's saying
on this track could easily be applied to
her but then there are some bits and
details that don't seem to run parallel
so maybe there are moments where it's
pointed at someone else and even if that
is the case there's most certainly a
deafening internal struggle going on in
this track as there is with nearly every
other moment on this lp the devastating
screams the skull crushing beats this is
easily one of black dresses most
unforgiving songs however it is pretty
clear that gay ugly and hard to
understand is most definitely doing a
lot of lashing out a lot of
externalizing shout out to bigfrida new
orleans bounce music every track
ever made for nyc drag balls before
rupaul made being gay uncool further
into the track there is all of this
in a way self parody commentary on uh
what is on trend for queer music and
maybe even you know assessing whether or
not black dresses fits into that
generally off my old cd you could copy a
track sell it to road runner make your
money back it's the corniest put
travis barker on it oh my god what the
is your problem yeah there's a lot
of mockery on this track about the
watering down of again what is
essentially queer music and packaging it
in a way to just make it easier to sell
but at the same time black dresses also
cause their fans to question what they
get out of their art too you want my
suffering why do you want it so bad you
think it's hard i want softness i
want the gentleness that only you were
offered i want a peaceful life again
maybe making some fans come to terms
with the fact that maybe i am sort of
just kind of listening to the duo's
music for this a visceral feel of the
pain that they put into their music
because it's legitimately pain that
they're going through now night wish in
my opinion is not the strongest song on
the lp but it is uh most definitely some
interesting parting words i used to want
to mean something to somebody but people
never see the side of you you want to be
which um
is maybe the most universally true thing
on this record that i think is said from
here we kind of go through the track
emotionally as if we are
experiencing a bit of a moment of
clarity and finding solace in the fact
that we are able to
create art and communicate with others
through that art saying let's still try
to have fun
at the very end of the song for me this
track really kind of like defines the
end of
a feeling that this record is going
through it's almost like this lp
was seeing black dresses as a duo
struggle through a very intensely dark
episode now whether or not this means
sort of like the end of a series of
narratives from their past couple of
records or is this just you know some
kind of painful moment that due to
mental and emotional struggles that are
ongoing that they will sort of like move
through once again into the future sort
of like a repeated existential crisis uh
i don't know but at least like for now
in terms of the music the duo has
released up until this point this
certainly does seem to be like a very
strong explosive
finishing point for a lot of what they
have been singing and rapping and
writing about for the past couple of
years in their music so again while this
may be one of black dresses shorter
projects sure i still think it plays an
imperative role when you're talking
about all of the
song topics and kind of song concepts
they have been delivering up until this
point and if you've enjoyed any of black
dresses stuff
up till now like some of their most
explosive material is on here and you
certainly wouldn't want to miss that
feeling a strong seven to a light eight
on this one tran position have you given
this record a listen did you love it did
you hate it what would you rate it
you're the best you're the best what
should i review next hit the like if you
like please subscribe and please don't
cry hit the bell as well over here next
to my head it's another video that you
can check out hit that up or the link to
subscribe to the channel anthony fantano
black dresses forever
